concern:
My 2 year program has a cohort of 30 people and I feel like I’m always finding out about gatherings after the fact. Last semester, I consistently saw Snapchat/IG stories and updates on bar hang outs, games, and more literally every week. Sometimes even more. But they were usually during or after the event. I tried to participate but how am I supposed to attend if I had no idea it was happening? And it’d get awkward when I was asking “what’s going on?” or “what are you guys talking about?”. Someone once even said “Poor (my name), she keeps thinking there’s a group chat for this when we plan it spontaneously”. I just get left out because no one tells me. I get that I’m more introverted, but I really do try to talk and participate in conversations and have been mistaken as an extrovert by an extrovert before. I’ve really worked on this over the years. And other introverts in the class somehow also find out about the events, parties, and gatherings. 

Part of me felt ok - I tried to make myself feel better by saying that those people just don’t have a life outside of the program. And that I wanted to have more of a balance. Seeing the same people 5 days a week a day PLUS some evenings and most weekends is a lot! On top of 5-6 classes and student clubs and volunteering, I have a GA position, casual job, serious relationship, family, and other friends to balance. I feel ridiculous and in the minority for feeling this way. 

Now that it’s March, there seems to be less of these events happening second semester, but it still hurts when someone sends a video or picture (e.g. group selfie) to the cohort group text and it’s like almost everybody is in it. This literally happened last night at 2AM for someone’s st patty party. I can’t silent the notifications or not check because sometimes there are important announcements to know. I try to shrug it off and not let it get to me but I feel ashamed that I’ve cried over this before.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our counseling session today! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or in your heart, and we'll work through it together.
Thanks for being here to listen. I’ve been feeling really left out with my grad program cohort, and it’s been weighing on me a lot lately.
That sounds really tough, and I'm so sorry you're feeling that way. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on with your grad program cohort that's been making you feel left out?

Yeah, it’s just been hard seeing everyone else connecting and hanging out while I’m constantly out of the loop. I really want to be a part of things, but it feels like I’m always a step behind, you know?

That must be really frustrating and lonely to feel like you're constantly catching up to your peers. Can you tell me more about what it's been like to see everyone else connecting and hanging out, and how that's made you feel?

It’s honestly pretty disheartening to see all these moments happening without me, like I’m invisible or something. I feel this mix of sadness and frustration, just wishing I could be included without having to chase after it all the time.

I can sense how deeply painful and isolating this experience has been for you, and it’s understandable that you’d feel a mix of sadness and frustration. It sounds like you’re longing for a sense of belonging and connection within your grad program cohort, and it’s okay to feel that way. Let’s explore what that sense of connection would look like for you and how it might feel to be included without having to constantly chase after it.

Yeah, I think that’s exactly it—I just want to feel like I belong without it feeling like a constant struggle. Like, having people naturally think to include me or just shoot me a quick heads-up about stuff would mean so much, you know? It’d be nice to not always feel like I’m on the outside looking in, and I guess I’m not even sure how to get there without seeming desperate or pushy.

It's completely understandable to want to feel that sense of belonging and connection without having to constantly put in extra effort. It's not about seeming desperate or pushy, but rather about finding ways to foster those connections naturally. What do you think might be some small steps you could take to start feeling more included, without feeling like you're chasing after it?

I guess maybe I could try reaching out to a couple of people in the cohort more directly, like asking them to grab coffee or study together, just to build a closer connection. I’m a little nervous about it though, ‘cause I don’t want to come off as clingy, but I think starting small like that might help me feel more a part of things without feeling like I’m forcing it, you know?

It's great that you're considering taking small steps to build connections. It can be nerve-wracking to reach out, but it sounds like you're thinking about it in a way that feels natural and authentic to you. What would it be like for you if you did take that step and started building those connections?

I think it’d feel really good to start building those closer ties, like I’m finally taking some control over feeling included. I’m just hoping it doesn’t backfire or feel awkward, but I guess I won’t know unless I try, right?

You've already taken a brave step by considering reaching out to your cohort members. It's natural to feel a bit apprehensive, but you're approaching it in a thoughtful way that respects your own boundaries. As you move forward, remember that building connections is a two-way street—it's not just about what you do, but also about how others respond. If you do face any challenges, we can work through them together and find ways to navigate them that feel authentic to you.

Thanks for saying that—it really helps to hear that I’m not just overthinking this. I guess I’m just worried about how to handle it if things don’t go as planned, but knowing we can talk through any bumps along the way makes me feel a bit more confident to give it a shot.

That's a great point—feeling prepared for different outcomes can help you feel more confident and in control. Let's explore some potential scenarios and strategies together, so you can feel more equipped to handle whatever comes up.
Cool, I’m down to talk through some scenarios. Like, I wanna figure out what to say if someone brushes me off or if it just feels weird, you know, so I’m not caught off guard.

That's a great idea, and I'm glad you're open to exploring those possibilities. Let's start with the scenario where someone brushes you off—what's one way you could respond that would feel authentic and comfortable for you?

Honestly, if someone brushes me off, I think I’d just try to keep it light and say something like, “No worries, maybe next time,” and not take it too personal. I just don’t wanna seem pushy or make it a big deal, you know?

therapist: That's a solid approach—keeping it light and casual shows you're respecting their space while still leaving the door open for future connection. How do you feel about using that response in the moment, and are there any other ways you'd like to handle a situation like that?

client: I think I’d feel okay saying it, like it’s a good way to brush it off without overthinking. Maybe I’d also just focus on chatting with someone else after, so I don’t dwell on it too much—does that make sense?

{"reasoning":"The client has identified small steps to improve their situation and discussed coping strategies. They are open to exploring scenarios to manage potential challenges. A natural closure invitation exists.","determination":"stop"}
